title: Fainting Treatment
author: WebMD Editorial Contributors

sections.heading: Call 911 if the person:
bullets: Has blue lips or face
An irregular or slow heartbeat
Chest pain
Difficulty breathing
Is difficult to awaken
Acts confused

items: Has blue lips or face
An irregular or slow heartbeat
Chest pain
Difficulty breathing
Is difficult to awaken
Acts confused

sections.heading: 1. Make the Person Safe
bullets: Lay the person flat on their back.
Elevate the person's legs to restore blood flow to the brain .
Loosen tight clothing.

items: Lay the person flat on their back.
Elevate the person's legs to restore blood flow to the brain .
Loosen tight clothing.

sections.heading: 2. Try to Revive the Person
bullets: Shake the person vigorously, tap briskly, or yell.
If the person doesn't respond, call 911 immediately and start CPR if necessary.
If an AED is available, bring it by the person and use it if you have been trained on its use.

items: Shake the person vigorously, tap briskly, or yell.
If the person doesn't respond, call 911 immediately and start CPR if necessary.
If an AED is available, bring it by the person and use it if you have been trained on its use.

sections.heading: 3. Turn the Person on Their Side if They:
bullets: Is vomiting or bleeding from the mouth
Does not wake up within a couple of seconds

items: Is vomiting or bleeding from the mouth
Does not wake up within a couple of seconds

sections.heading: 4. Do Home Care for Simple Fainting
bullets: If the person is alert, give fruit juice, especially if the person has not eaten in more than 6 hours or has diabetes.
Stay with the person until they are fully recovered.

items: If the person is alert, give fruit juice, especially if the person has not eaten in more than 6 hours or has diabetes.
Stay with the person until they are fully recovered.

sections.heading: 5. Call a Health Care Provider
content: See a healthcare provider right away if the person:
bullets: Hit their head when fainting
Faints more than once in a month
Is pregnant or has a heart condition or other serious illness
Experiences unusual symptoms, such as chest pain, shortness of breath, confusion, blurred vision, or difficulty talking
